ncsd_python¶

NCSD is short for No Core Slater Determinant.

ncsd is the code that, given details about a nucleus, finds its wavefunction by solving the many-body Schrödinger equation using an expansion in harmonic oscillator basis states.

It uses Slater determinants to ensure that the end result is antisymmetric with respect to particle exchange as required by symmetry properties of QCD.

There are two top-level modules here, and each has some sub-modules full of helper functions.

ncsd_multi.py¶

A module to facilitate running ncsd with many nuclei.

It takes sets of inputs for multiple ncsd runs. Then, for each run:

  1. It makes a folder so each run’s output is contained, copies .exe file.

  2. In each folder, creates a mfdp.dat file and a batch script.

  3. Runs each bash script at the end, if desired. Otherwise you run them.

To run this file, manually change the values in this file then run:

python ncsd_multi.py
ncsd_python.ncsd_multi.int_dir = '/Users/callum/Desktop/npsm/interactions'¶

Paths: change the values as needed, but don’t remove the realpath. Empty string = current working directory, relative paths are relative to there.

ncsd_python.ncsd_multi.machine = 'cedar'¶

Machine: must be one of “cedar”, “summit”, “local”.

ncsd_python.ncsd_multi.man_params = <multi_modules.data_structures.ManParams object>¶

Manual Parameters:

  • specify all as single parameter or list []

  • if you use a list, we’ll make N ncsd runs, where N is the maximum length of a list made here.

  • list of attributes is in multi_modules/data_structures.py, man_keys.

  • default parameters are at the bottom of multi_modules/data_structures.py

ncsd_python.ncsd_multi.run(man_params, int_dir, ncsd_path, working_dir, machine, run=True)¶

Do you want to run the code automatically? If so, set run=True

output_plotter.py¶

A module for helping to deal with data from NCSD output files, and saving that data to various formats (e.g. png plots, xmgrace files).

You can run this file by adjusting some parameters within it, and then running:

python output_plotter.py

If you’re okay with default values, you can run:

python output_plotter.py -f filename

And if you ran ncsd with ncsd_multi.py, this file will be automatically called at the end of the batch script.

ncsd_python.output_plotter.grace_plotter_path = '/Users/callum/Desktop/npsm/docs/grace_spectra_plotter.exe'¶

The path to grace_spectra_plotter.exe

ncsd_python.output_plotter.make_plot_files(output_paths=[], save_dir=None, out_types=['xmgrace'], skip_Nmax=[], max_state=1e+100, get_online_data=False)¶

This takes ncsd output filenames, and exports the data to each format listed in out_types.

output_paths:

A list of ncsd output files, from which to make plot files

save_dir:

Where should we save the plot files?

out_types:

What kinds of output do you want. List, e.g. [“xmgrace”, “csv”]

skip_Nmax:

A list of Nmax values to skip

max_state:

The maximum numbered state to consider

ncsd_python.output_plotter.max_state = 1e+100¶

If you have, say, 10 states and only want to plot 8, set max_state=8. If you don’t want a max state, set max_state to a huge number, e.g. 1e100

ncsd_python.output_plotter.out_types = ['xmgrace', 'matplotlib', 'csv']¶

out_types is a list of the kinds of output you want. - Possible output types: xmgrace, csv, matplotlib - The output is saved in the same directory as this script.

ncsd_python.output_plotter.output_paths = ['/Users/callum/Desktop/npsm/_ncsd_output/Li8_n3lo-NN3Nlnl-srg2.0_Nmax0-10.20']¶

List of paths to ncsd output files

ncsd_python.output_plotter.save_dir = None¶

save_dir: where to save the plot files, formatted as a string or None. - None = save in the same directory as the first output_paths file - blank string = current working directory - some other string = save to that directory, include a final slash

ncsd_python.output_plotter.skip_Nmax = []¶

If there are any Nmax values you want to skip, put them here, e.g. [0,2,4]. If you don’t want to skip any, use [].
